Article.ArticleTitle: Influence of oxygen availability on the activities of ammonia-oxidizing archaea.

AbstractText: Recent studies point to the importance of oxygen (O<sub>2</sub> ) in controlling the distribution and activity of marine ammonia-oxidizing archaea (AOA), one of the most abundant prokaryotes in the ocean. The AOA are associated with regions of low O<sub>2</sub> tension in oceanic oxygen minimum zones (OMZs), and O<sub>2</sub> availability is suggested to influence their production of the ozone-depleting greenhouse gas nitrous oxide (N<sub>2</sub> O). We show that marine AOA available in pure culture sustain high ammonia oxidation activity at low μM O<sub>2</sub> concentrations, characteristic of suboxic regions of OMZs (<10 µM O<sub>2</sub> ), and that atmospheric concentrations of O<sub>2</sub> may inhibit the growth of some environmental populations. We quantify the increasing N<sub>2</sub> O production by marine AOA with decreasing O<sub>2</sub> tensions, consistent with the plausibility of an AOA contribution to the accumulation of N<sub>2</sub> O at the oxic-anoxic redox boundaries of OMZs. Variable sensitivity to peroxide also suggests that endogenous or exogenous reactive oxygen species are of importance in determining the environmental distribution of some populations.
